docs.lead_paragraph: Where There's Smoke... For nonsmokers who are bothered by cigarette smoke in stuffy offices and restaurants, last week's report from the Surgeon General was cause for both alarm and relief. In the strongest statement yet by a high-ranking Federal official on the risks of ''passive smoking,'' Dr. C. Everett Koop said there is ''very solid'' evidence that cigarette smoke poses a health risk to nonsmokers.

headline.main: Surgeon General Links Smoking to Lung Disease in Nonsmokers

byline.original: By IRVIN MOLOTSKY; Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: The Surgeon General of the United States, C. Everett Koop, said today that there was "very solid" evidence that nonsmokers had suffered lung disease from exposure to cigarette smoke. Dr. Koop acknowledged that it was the strongest statement ever made by a high-ranking Federal health official on the phenomenon, which has been labeled "passive smoking." We try to be eminently fair and try not to overstate the case," the Surgeon General said as he issued an annual report on smoking and health, but now "the evidence is very solid." Asked if there was provable relation between cigarette smoke and illness and death among nonsmokers, Dr. Koop said yes but added that the supporting data were not included in the report.
